instruction: What metric was chosen to evaluate the performance of the models for detecting internal mechanical damage in blueberries and how far can this metric go?
Output:
The metric chosen to evaluate the performance of the models for detecting internal mechanical damage in blueberries is accuracy, precision, recall, F1-score, and false positive rate. These metrics are used to quantify the performance of the classifiers in detecting internal mechanical damage of blueberries using hyperspectral transmittance data. Additionally, ROC curves and Precision-Recall curves are plotted to visualize the performance of the classifiers.

The accuracy metric measures the overall correctness of the classification results. Precision measures the proportion of correctly classified positive instances out of all instances classified as positive. Recall measures the proportion of correctly classified positive instances out of all actual positive instances. F1-score is the harmonic mean of precision and recall, providing a balanced measure of the classifier's performance. The false positive rate quantifies the rate at which the classifier incorrectly classifies negative instances as positive.

instruction: What are the traditional machine learning algorithms used in this study and how do they compare to the deep convolutional neural networks in terms of performance for detecting internal mechanical damage in blueberries?
Output:
The traditional machine learning algorithms used for detecting internal mechanical damage in blueberries are Sequential Minimal Optimization (SMO), Linear Regression (LR), Random Forest (RF), Bagging, and Multilayer Perceptron (MLP).

In terms of performance for detecting internal mechanical damage in blueberries, the deep convolutional neural networks (CNN) outperform the traditional machine learning algorithms. The fine-tuned ResNet and ResNeXt achieve higher average accuracy and F1-score compared to the traditional machine learning methods. 

The average accuracy and F1-score for ResNet are 0.8844 and 0.8952, respectively, while for ResNeXt they are 0.8784 and 0.8905, respectively. On the other hand, the traditional machine learning algorithms achieve lower average accuracy and F1-score. 

The average accuracy and F1-score for SMO are 0.8082 and 0.8268, for LR they are 0.7606 and 0.7796, for RF they are 0.7314 and 0.7529, for Bagging they are 0.7113 and 0.7339, and for MLP they are 0.7827 and 0.7971, respectively
